poem:
Title: "Of Ink and Steel"

With blunter pen and sharper sword,
Beneath concrete's mute discourse,
Across the emerald-scape, the word 
Echoes uniform, and hoarse.

Men captured far from fleeting peace,
Their plea - to form the news,
'Let tongues with unifying grease,
The public mind amuse.'

Yet, shade of bias stains the air,
And truth, in whispers, dies -
In echoes lost, both here and there,
The cry of unity lies.
prompt: You are the poet Philip Larkin. You woke up this morning feeling passionate. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘Journalists see their role as helping to win’: how Israeli TV is covering Gaza war The TikTok videos feature Israeli soldiers, standing under the concrete blast barriers of a military base, in front of a rolling green landscape or beside an armoured vehicles. Most are in full military gear, in settings that make clear these are men at war, with one message to their country’s journalists. “If you don’t have something unifying to say, just". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
